Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 07:47PM nmiller1978 wrote: Taxol/Avastin knocked out ALL of my mets in three months with next to zero side effects. I talked to my onc today who confirmed the rumors and stated that in his opinion, it's likley that Avastin will be a thing of the past by the end of this year. However....he also said that for those for whom it's WORKING, there's no way the insurance companies would pull you off of it, that would be unethical and the lawsuits woudl be insane so that gave me some comfort. Hope this proves to be the case for all of us!

Posts.Content: nmiller1978 wrote: Hello all, I'm not entirely sure how to report this or what the reaction may be, but I am so very hopeful that this will be encouraging news to some of you who are TN and terrified. OK, here goes..I am 32, BRCA 1, TN and was diagnosed 4/10 with metastatic disease in the form of two large liver lesions, this was confirmed by liver biopsy and PET/CT. I began tx the end of April 2010, Taxol/Avastin, once weekly, three weeks on, one week off. My first follow up pet scan was July, 2010. Complete resolution of both liver lesions and complete resolution of both tumors in the right breast. Yay!! I remained NED on that combo until 12/10 when a PET/CT showed slight progression in my right breast, I wasn't convinced and even though my onc told me I was nuts, I insisted on a biopsy. It came back positive for malignancy ( surprise, surprise) so we switched to Inaparib (PARP inhibitor) with gem/carbo. I've been on that ever since. My tumor (palpable in Dec) began to soften and reduce almost immediately, 3 scans later and still clean in April, I pushed for surgery. My onc said he thought it was way too risky because of the aggressive nature of TN, I pushed anyway. Had my BMX 6/1. My pathology came back negative for everything. EVERYTHING!!! no evidence of cancer, current or previous on even a microscopic level. Nothing. They were so flabbergasted by my results that they took more tissue out of the sample and ran it twice. Nada, 0/ 24 nodes and tissue all clear. I have the same tissue as a person who's never had cancer. Continuing forward, I'm going back to PARP and if I continue to scan clear for another 12 months, then I'll be done with tx and will scan only every three months. My doctor looked at me today and said, "this is the first time in my career that I've been able to tell a metastatic patient that there might be hope". A small sliver, but there it is nonetheless. I remember logging on to these boards and thinking, if I can just find one, just ONE person with liver mets who is TN with some sort of hope than I'll know it can be done. I know how early days it is and I know how rare this is. But I firmly believe if you can put your mind in front of your body that's half the battle. I hope this helps bolster some of you. I'm still afraid to really share my story for fear of jinxing myself, but I also know this is a blessing from God and is meant to be shared. I have had awesome care and have definitely been my own advocate but it is by far my faith that has strengthened me. I believe somebody wrote recently that there must be long term survivors but that they don't really post here because, well, this chapter's closed for them. This does happen, probably more often than we think bur it does. I know ASCO says this drug is underperforming but I would tend to disagree...Love and prayers to you all.  Nicole  Dx 3/28/2010, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/24 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 08:36AM nmiller1978 wrote: Everybody thank you so much for your words of encouragement. It is exciting but more than a little scary because this is completely uncharted territory. I go back to treatment on Tuesday, so several of us will be on the same schedule ;-) Towny, I am also in NY, but in the Saratoga Springs area, I treat at Albany Med through NYOH which is a division of US Oncology. One thing I do have to caution you guys about is cancer assays...I don't have all the information, but have been told by many including several of my doctors that these tests are not yet reliable and exorbitantly expensive. Please, please research it further before spending that kind of money, I know we stage IV girls are often preyed upon because of the desperation of our prognosis. There is a thread addressing this specifically on TNBCfoundation.org under the metastatic forum.  Also, I've been told that PARP efficacy IS tied specifically to BRCA mutations and even more specifically BRCA 1. TNs who are BRCA 1 generally have more basal like tumors, these types of tumors are more likely to respond to this treatment than non basal like tumors. That's what I've been told by my oncologist and what my research has uncovered. Good Luck to all starting PARP trials soon. I would recommend you stock up on Colace now!! I was "regular" my entire life, even on 8 months of Taxol/Avastin... this combo changed all that quickly!! Hugs and prayers!! God Bless you all, Nicole
Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 07:40PM nmiller1978 wrote: Dell!!! So happy to hear this but not surprised!! Have had two scans since my mastectomy and both were still completely clear. This combo is doing awesome things for some of us, I just hope it continues ( I think it will!!) Enjoy your wonderful miraculous news and the blessings you have been given!!! Nicole

Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 03:31PM nmiller1978 wrote: Hey girls, @Dell, I've been on this protocol since the beginning of December 2010 so I'm coming up on a year!! And yes my scans have been completely clear for some time now. In March the tumor in my breast was significantly smaller and by May 1st the SUV in both breasts was identical, less than a 1.0 but some uptake because I had dense tissue. No lymph nodes ever lit up after my diagnosing PET in Match 2010. My liver has been completely clear since July 2010. When I had my mastectomy in June all 24 lymph nodes were clear and my tissue (all of it) was completely cancer free, not even a micro met to be found. I guess this is pretty rare. My first post surgical scan was Aug 12, 2011 and that was still perfect. My next one is the first week of November but I feel pretty good about it. Stay tuned!! @Terri, thanks for your support. I had to go out on a limb and disagree with my doctor but I knew in my hear that it was the right decision. Trust your gut!! Nobody has your best interests at heart more than you!! Hugs and prayers to all Nicole
Posts.Title: Encouraging PARP news nmiller1978 bottkota

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 08:45AM nmiller1978 wrote: Oh, and BKJ66, typically surgery in Stage IV TNs is a rarity although it is becoming more common place. The reason being surgery takes car of the localized disease but doesn't treat anything metastatic. Because we are not hormone sensitive, hormonals and AIs don't work on us, these drugs can be taken while "off" chemo for surgery, with TNs, all defenses are down for surgery. So in my case, even though the primary tumors were taken care of by surgery, the liver mets (theoretically) would be left to grow unchecked. That's why the aggressiveness of TN is such a big factor, 6 weeks off chemo without good control of the disease can be a total crapshoot: yes you want the primary gone, but those aren't the ones that kill you. So, for now we are hopeful that my liver mets responded the way my primary did. Won't know until my next scan for sure, but that's the way it usually works. Also, I never had AC, Taxol/Avastin for 8 months & the PARP trial since 12/10. Hope this helps!  God Bless Nicole

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 03:40AM nmiller1978 wrote: I'm not sure about all PET scans but I know mine are only "eyes to thighs" and because of this can miss a large portion of the brain. I had a PET scan on 10/24/12 that showed completely NED. I told my MO I was experiencing some right sided weakness in my leg and hand. A brain MRI was ordered and they found a 4 cm met in my left frontal lobe. The PET doesn't go that high so it would have been missed completely if I hadn't said something. If you have any doubt, ask for an MRI. Best of luck. Nicole
Posts.Title: Brain mets detection bhd1 LuvRVing

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 08:46AM nmiller1978 wrote: Hi there! I was diagnosed in April 2010 TNBC BRCA 1 with liver mets and suspicious lung nodules. I did Taxol/Avavstin until 12/2010 when I had a local recurrence in my right breast, my liver (  which was biopsied to confirm my cancer ) has never shown up since my initial staging PET. After my local recurrence I was switched to Carbo/Gemzar/BSI 201 which is a PARP trial. I am still on this twice a week. Completed BMX in June 2011 and Rads in Dec 2011. Have continued to scan clean since Feb 2011 and just had another one 4 weeks ago. I, too, scan every three months per the requirements of the PARP trial. The advice that Bottkota gave is invaluable. Be your own advocate!! My Onc is great, but a little on the conservative side. I had to BEG for a BMX. His reason for concern: TNs can't have any TX during surgery and recovery the way women with ER/PR+ can so there would be NO defenses in place for up to 8 weeks, this made him (understandably) nervous. I came across Hydeskate's story and PM'd her some questions. Her results are really what put my onc over the top on moving forward with the BMX. So ABSOLUTELY do your own research! ( Thanks again Heidi). Best of luck on your journey. As long as you're breathing, there is ALWAYS hope! Love and prayers, Nicole
Posts.Title: TNBC with liver mets Mel_H mkkjd60

Posts.Content: nmiller1978 wrote: Hi ladies, I am new here, diagnosed March of this year at age 31. Triple negative, mets to liver. Holy wake up call Batman!!! I have been on Taxol/ Avastin since April and just rec'd results from my first CT/PET since being diagnosed. My results were amazing. Complete response according to my onc. Both (large!!) spots on my liver are gone and both tumors in my right breast are completely resolved. I was so excited to recieve this news BUT my onc has decided to continue the Taxol/Avastin without further discussion.  Ladies BELIEVE ME, I know what a monumental blessing this news is, I lost my mother to this disesase only 5 years ago and would have doneanything for scan results like this for her. Maybe I'm being overly optimistic here but is there anything else besides more chemo? As a Triple Neg I realize chemo is pretty much my only option but was curious, has anyone tried site specific cryoablation? I feel good on Taxol, few side effects and want to hit this as hard as i can while I still feel this good. Any suggestions? Please help. Have been lurking since my diagnosis and already feel like I know a lot of you. Nicole Dx 3/28/2010, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/24 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: New, need advice... nmiller1978 nmiller1978

Posts.Content: nmiller1978 wrote: Hello friends, Recently started a clinical trial with Carbo/Gemzar and Inaparib. It's definitely working its magic on the cancer as my primary tumor was reduced by more than a third after only two weeks but it seems it's "tickiling" my liver as well. Liver enzymes in just 4 weeks have been climbing steadily from 30s to 164 to 180 and then today 338!!! Tenfold in four weeks. I was last scanned 12/08/10 and there was nada anywhere but my right breast (had two large liver lesions at dx 4/10). Onc is insistent that this is chemo related and not indicative of new disease in the liver (since the primary site has reduced so quickly). Because my enzymes were so high they withheld tx today. My question, is this par for the course? I know Gem is known to cause liver issues but these numbers are alarming to me. Any ideas on how to calm it down? My Onc is conservative & totally against milk thistle, turmeric, etc. but I wold love any input. I don't want to miss anymore treatments on a drug that seems to be working so well!!! Dx 3/28/2010, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/24 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: nmiller1978 wrote: Hi everybody, been wondering if this has ever happened to any of you. Had my blood pressure taken yesterday at MD appt. Creeping toward high since I've been on Avastin...yesterday it was 142/90. So today before TX, the nurse took my blood pressure again, this time in my right arm.My primary tumor was in my right breast, although I've never had anything surgical done, they've always taken my BP on the left. So imagine my surprise when the machine read 122/86!! Then checked against the left arm which this time read 146/97!! What the hell??? I asked and her response was....some people are just built that way, could be your vascular system. Huh?!! Can you say "brush off"?!! Needless to say I have a call in to my MD but can any of you shed some light on this?? Just curious!! Thanks! Posts.Content: nmiller1978 wrote: Hello all, Kind of a weird question. Had my first PET since BMX in June. All clear metastatically (yay!!!) Nothing showing in liver, lungs, etc. BUT, there was some uptake noted in the "former breast area" whatever the hell that means. Didn't get a value in it but I know it was slight. This was noted on both sides with more uptake noted in the right side (where the tumor was and where I had 24 nodes removed). I was told this is most likely post surgical scarring and healing and not to worry as it's only been 10 weeks since surgery. I know the radiologist so he reads these stat as a favor but of course NOW I need to ask a question about a report I'm not even supposed to have access to!  Onc is on vacay til I see him on Tuesday. Let me finish by adding my pathology from surgery was PRISTINE, not even anything microscopic found. AND nothing has ever shown up on the left side. Radiologist said he was just being thorough but I of course am panicking. Anybody have any experience with this? It's gonna be a loooong weekend! Posts.Title: First scan after mastectomy nmiller1978 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2014 09:21AM nmiller1978 wrote: FierceBlue, Just posted on brain mets sisters, so hard to find tns with brain mets! Your profile didn't say whether you are triple negative but I'm assuming you are. Ok, first off do you have good disease control from the neck down? Second there are two schools of thought with SRS vs WBR: wbr can only be used once and can have some pretty decent, sorta scary side effects. OR which is what I wished I had done, do wbr first then use SRS as a boost to go after the little ones. I opted for SRS first for fear of losing my hair. Stupid vanity. Now I'm out of options except for trials. We shall see!! Either way, get a second opinion!' Nicole

Posts.Title: Avastin News =A call for help stage4triplenegsurvivor Dilly

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2014 09:24AM nmiller1978 wrote: Hey Dallas,  completed wbr over a year ago. Still me still cognitively intact. Did 15 rounds. Lost all my hair,  got it all back. Took about two months to start coming back and I definitely had the reverse Mohawk thing you read about, but it filled in slowly and a year later it's thick & curly. Side effects vary. Personally fatigue was my biggest issue. Sleep when you're tired but STAY ACTIVE. Eat well and take all your meds as prescribed.  Steroids suck but they are necessary. Listen and follow your docs orders. That MD after his name doesn't make him god but it does give him credibility. Do get a second opinion at a research or university hospital. If both docs are in agreement I would do it. They're attempting to reduce what's called tumor burden. And the great thing is you still have the option of SRS to clean up any new spots.  Don't forget, you feel fine: go by how you FEEL, not how some piece of paper says you should feel. Best of luck. The thought is much scarier than the reality.  Love & prayers Nicole
